Where Do You Get Information When Twitter Is Gone?

376 words written on Sun, Apr 15 2018

I covered where to find online community after leaving Facebook but what about Twitter? Twitter is good not just for community (in fact it‚Äôs no longer really good for that) but more so for surfacing interesting links.

The first answer to the question is already answered in my previous post: distributed Twitter-like services, Reddit and RSS.

There is one other place where I get most of my quality information and links, and that is curated email lists. Here are my favorites.

The Offscrean Dispatch, ‚ÄúA hand-picked selection of great apps, accessories, and articles in your inbox every Tuesday,‚Äù from the makers of Offscreen Magazine (‚Äúa print magazine with a thoughtful, human-centred take on technology and the web‚Äù).

Software Lead Weekly, ‚Äúa weekly email for busy people who care about people, culture and leadership.‚Äù

The Great Discontent, another print magazine‚Äôs weekly email newsletter. ‚Äú‚Ä¶inspiring conversations with today‚Äôs artists, makers, and risk-takers.‚Äù

You could subscribe to Boing Boing via RSS, or subscribe to their curated newsletter. One of the web‚Äôs originals (since 1995).

AngelList‚Äôs weekly newsletter is focused on startup jobs, but is well crafted and thematic every week.

If you‚Äôre in Dallas and into tech, Dallas Innovates‚Äôs daily email is worth it.

For productivity nerds, Time Dorks is by the authors of Sprint. They‚Äôre writing another book called Make Time.

Simon Sinek‚Äôs daily aphorisms are actually really good.

This is a plug for a friend, but if you‚Äôre into really well-crafted cultural critisicm, you can get about weekly doses for $1 a month by becoming a patron of Howard Ingham.

Ditto, except this time philosophy, from Peter Rollins.

Dan Pink‚Äôs Pinkcast, biweekly, brief chunks of good content from the productivity and motivation guru.

The Athletic‚Äôs Fun Times Friday. Cycling apparel company‚Äôs weekly links about mostly things other than cycling.

Last, and far from least, Rodens Explorers Club, sent a few times a year by Craig Mod, a thoughtful writer, photographer and traveler.

Whew! That‚Äôs a lot, and not all that I‚Äôm subscribed to (I left off more specific topics, like education, meditation, product development and specific technologies). I should probably unsubscribe from a lot of stuff.
